Uses MAC addresses to forward traffic efficiently

Can be configured (VLANs, QoS, port control). Used in larger or business networks.

â–ªï¸ Unmanaged Switch

Plug-and-play, no configuration. Used in homes or small offices.

ğŸ§  Exam Tip: Switches = Layer 2, unless it's a Layer 3 switch, which routes too.

ğŸ“¶ Access Points

Extends Wi-Fi coverage. Acts as a bridge between wired and wireless.

ğŸ§  Exam Tip: Not the same as a router, but often built-in.

ğŸ§µ Patch Panel

Central point for cable organization. No intelligenceâ€”just physical connection points.

ğŸ§  Tip: Think of it as the networkâ€™s â€œphonebookâ€ for cables.

ğŸ”¥ Firewall

Filters incoming/outgoing traffic based on rules. Can be software or hardware. Protects against unauthorized access.

ğŸ§  Exam Tip: Look for scenarios involving port blocking, IP filtering, or packet inspection.

âš¡ Power over Ethernet (PoE)

Sends power + data through Ethernet cable.

â–ªï¸ Injectors

Add power to Ethernet lines for non-PoE switches.

â–ªï¸ PoE Switch

Built-in power delivery, no injector needed.

â–ªï¸ PoE Standards

  • IEEE 802.3af (PoE) = 15.4W
  • IEEE 802.3at (PoE+) = 25.5W

ğŸ§  Tip: Used for powering APs, IP cameras, VoIP phones.

ğŸ§© Hub

Repeats all network traffic to all ports (no intelligence). Causes network collisions (uses CSMA/CD).

Obsolete, replaced by switches.

ğŸ§  Exam Tip: If it floods traffic â†’ itâ€™s a hub, not a switch.

ğŸ“¡ Cable Modem

Connects to ISP via coaxial cable. Converts signal for Internet use (DOCSIS standard).

ğŸ§  Tip: Common in home internet setups.

â˜ï¸ DSL (Digital Subscriber Line)

Uses telephone lines for internet. Slower than cable/fiber.

ğŸ§  Tip: Often found in rural areas.

ğŸ”¦ ONT (Optical Network Terminal)

Device that converts fiber signals to Ethernet. Used in FTTH (Fiber to the Home) installations.

ğŸ§  Tip: If the scenario includes fiber, look for ONT.

ğŸ’» NIC (Network Interface Card)

Hardware that connects a device to a network. Can be wired (Ethernet) or wireless (Wi-Fi).

ğŸ§  Tip: Found inside computers, printers, etc.

ğŸ§  SDN (Software-Defined Networking)

Controls network via software, not hardware. Used in cloud networks and datacenters.

Centralized controller dynamically manages traffic.

ğŸ§  Tip: Flexible, programmableâ€”modern enterprise networks love SDN.

âœ… Final Tips

  • Switch = efficient, Hub = dumb
